Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: Scaling the University Innovation Fellows Program to Catalyze Student Engagement and Change in Higher Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the NSF Innovation Corps for Learning Program (I-Corps L), this project will develop ways to increase the scale and impact of University Innovation Fellows (UIF) program at Stanford University. In higher education, there is widespread interest in developing ways to provide students with the knowledge, skills and attitudes that they need to solve complex problems of the 21st century. The University Innovation Fellows program prepares and empowers university students to make lasting changes at their schools to address this issue. Through UIF, student leaders collaborate with faculty and administrators to promote and embed innovation, entrepreneurship and design thinking to enhance the educational experience of all students.

While there is no single prescription for which strategies and activities will be effective in higher education, each institution can develop context-appropriate strategies based on understanding best practices, information about what has worked and not worked in similar institutions, and innovative thinking. The University Innovation Fellows (UIF) program offers faculty a way to activate selected students to work alongside them in expanding the innovation and entrepreneurship ecosystem on campus. The program combines online experiential training with in-person gatherings in Silicon Valley. In the training, university students evaluate the landscape of learning opportunities and resources at their schools, and design a strategic plan to transform and enrich that landscape, by leveraging experiential learning techniques. Students who successfully complete the training (and become Fellows) are motivated and prepared to work alongside faculty as change agents. This program will provide year-round support for the Fellows via webinars and networking tools that allow students to share strategies across institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Innovation and Entrepreneurship (I&E) education has gained support in higher education, as a means to provide students with the knowledge, skills and attitudes needed to solve complex problems and compete in the economy of the future. However, integrating them into the existing structures and curricula -- or radically changing the existing models -- is stymied by the slow pace of change in academia. The University Innovation Fellows (UIF) is an innovative program empowers students to accelerate change, in collaboration with faculty and administrators, by expanding the innovation and entrepreneurship ecosystem at their schools. Over the past 5 years, 1,000 students from 185 institutions have undergone a custom training that combines experiential online learning with in-person events, preparing them to understand the landscape of learning opportunities available at their schools and giving them tools -- such as design thinking, lean startup and custom systems thinking frameworks -- to craft and lead strategic projects that will make a difference in the experience of their peers. Evaluation results showed a statistically significant increase in the innovation self-efficacy of the students that went through the UIF training. Fellows create opportunities on campus both to expose (e.g., TEDx, lectures, and workshops) and to engage (e.g., hackathons and competitions) their peers in I&E and design thinking. The data shows that Fellows have affected campus environments by engaging students as well as initiating sustainable institutional change, including the creation of new learning opportunities like courses and programs, as well as attracting new funding streams and physical infrastructure. Learn more about the program at universityinnovationfellows.org.

The program was co-created by Leticia Britos Cavagnaro and Humera Fasihuddin, as the student-centric initiative of the NSF-supported National Center for Engineering Pathways to Innovation (Epicenter), which operated from 2011 to 2016 supported by a $10 million grant from NSF (# 1125457). Starting in July 2015, both co-founders, mentored by Jay LeBoeuf of Real Industry, participated of the second national cohort of I-Corps for LearningTM. The team was seeking viable strategies for sustaining and scaling the program, whose training, curricula and model of networked community of practice had proven to be an effective and innovative methodology for activating students as agents of institutional change in higher education. Working in their favor was a revenue stream the program was already generating, albeit heavily subsidized by the Epicenter grant. The team conducted 117 customer discovery interviews and over 70 tests of 5 key hypotheses using Minimum Viable Products (MVP).

Building on the insights gathered during customer discovery and validation, our team achieved the following key outcomes:

  • We completed the successful transition of the program from the original NSF-supported center to a self-sustained core initiative of Stanford University's Hasso Plattner Institute of Design (d.school).

  • We doubled the fee contributed by the institutions to cover the students’ participation in the program, to compensate for the end of NSF subsidy. This strategy didn’t impact demand, with applications continuing to grow year after year.

  • We diversified the portfolio of offerings in order to meet emerging needs of our existing faculty customers, as well as acquire new ones. New offerings included:

    1. Expansion to global institutions, reaching a total of 8 countries to date, and receiving inquiries from more countries for the upcoming cohort. We have also expanded the types of institutions that participate, to include not only engineering and research focused schools, but also liberal arts colleges and other types of schools. Among these, we reach a good number of Minority Serving Institutions. See a list of participating institutions at: http://universityinnovationfellows.org/about-us/schools/

    2. A dedicated expansion into India, as a collaboration with Google, who provided financial and in-kind support. To date, we have trained 55 Indian students from 22 institutions. Learn more at: http://universityinnovationfellows.org/google-india-initiative/

    3. A brand new design thinking and experiential pedagogy workshop, helping university educators re-imagine their teaching and build new programs and centers. The workshop takes place at Stanford three times a year. Learn more at: https://dschool.stanford.edu/university-innovation/faculty-workshops).

These strategies combined allowed us to reach sustainability within the first year after the closure of the original NSF grant.

Overall, we strongly believe that our success in sustaining and scaling the University Innovation Fellows program will result in an important contribution to the transformation of higher education. The evidence we are collecting about the effectiveness of a student-driven strategy could be leveraged to attain change in other areas of academia (such as increasing access to college, and increasing diversity and inclusion), as well as outside of academia, finding the right analogs to the student change agents. Learn more about our social learning-based, student-driven strategies at http://universityinnovationfellows.org/designingforchange/.
